Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps Teams: Mobile Platform for Collecting, Analyzing, and Managing In-Field Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is a significantly improved in-field data collection and data analysis workflow. This technology leverages the widespread use of smartphones around the world by providing a robust digital platform with low hardware requirements for collecting and understanding data. By digitizing inputs from the beginning of the data collection process and providing live analysis, the platform reduces the cost, time, and expertise required to collect and understand the information contained within datasets. The technology can benefit diverse industries, but has particular application to municipal governments and NGOs, where project managers need to regularly monitor the effect of their program. Their ability to do so and make the necessary adjustments directly impact the effectiveness and efficiency of the projects. The technology has significant commercial potential beyond governments and NGOs, and impacts any industry that requires rapid and reliable data insights for decision making. Over time, the technology will make data collection and usage more accessible to empower average people to better advocate for their community.

This I-Corps project aims to explore the commercial potential of a fully digital in-field data platform. The technology allows any team to quickly collect and analyze in-field data. A robust software platform forms the core of the technology. The platform automatically tags data with GPS and time information and provides live visualization of data and team activity with minimal hardware requirements. Advanced mobile algorithms manage data caching and cloud uploading. These algorithms enable the platform to operate reliably in areas with intermittent internet connection and protect data during hardware crashes. This fully digital process reduces the cost and time required to compile and interpret in-field datasets so valuable insights can be gained quickly and cheaply to facilitate data-driven decision making. Over time, this work may also increase the accessibility of data to the public and empower citizens to better advocate for their communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the seven week NSF I-Corps program, the Flocktracker team conducted 105 primary customer interviews. The team started the program with a very broad customer segment: anyone who collects and uses geospatial data. During the first two weeks of the program, the team, pushed by the instructors, narrowed down our target customers to develop a deeper understanding of their needs. 

The first major surprise the team discovered is that urban data scientists in the US rarely collect their own data. Due to the high costs of labor and availability of existing datasets (such as the census, the American Community Survey, and data portals from state and city governments), US data scientists generally infer the information they need from existing datasets rather than collecting the exact data they need. 

Their biggest struggle is understanding and cross-correlating the various available datasets. In contrast, Flocktracker’s primary strength is in collecting new data, so the team pivoted to focus on disaster planning and response. Major disasters, such as floods or tornados, render all existing maps about the urban infrastructure obsolete so data about the current situation must be collected during the recovery efforts. However, additional interviews revealed that responders  prefer low-tech solutions because electricity and internet connection are often not guaranteed after a major disaster. Safety and coordination also depended on the responders strictly following established protocols, so they are very hesitant to re-train people on new tools. 

To make the problem more challenging, much of the re-training would need to take place at the disaster site because responders often come from all over the world. This led to the second major pivot to road asset managers, a customer segment that constantly collects geospatial data to track road and sidewalk conditions. The team learned that much of this work was still conducted by city employees filling out paper reports that must then be entered into computer databases, and employees were spending up to 2 hours a day on transcribing the paper reports. On the surface, this seemed like a perfect use case for Flocktracker to save the city money by streamlining the data collection process. However, interviews with planners and city managers around the country showed that most cities in the US have existing digital databases and infrastructure that were custom built over the past decades. Adapting our technology to interface with each city’s unique database makes scale-up prohibitively expensive for a startup, but they could be a suitable market once we gain traction elsewhere. 

Although the team did not find a viable market for Flocktracker during the seven week program, we developed valuable, transferable skills for technology commercialization that will serve us for the rest of our research and entrepreneurial careers. We took the lessons learned about the market conditions required for our technology to be successful and continued our customer discovery work. After over a year of additional customer discovery interviews testing different versions of our business hypothesis, the team eventually validated a viable initial customer segment: developing cities that are very early in setting up their digital infrastructure. Two members of the original team plan to launch a company in summer 2020.


Last Modified: 05/31/2020
Modified by: Roman Lubynsky
